channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine Fired U.S.-Made Missiles Into Russia for First Time, Officials Say
item.description: The attack came just days after President Biden gave Ukraine permission to use the weapons to strike targets inside Russia.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: John Hamilton/White Sands Missile Range, via Associated Press
item.media:description: President Biden on Sunday gave Ukraine authorization to use the U.S.-made Army Tactical Missile System, known as ATACMS, to strike inside Russia.

item.title: U.S. Envoy Visits Lebanon, Seeking Truce Between Israel and Hezbollah
item.description: The envoy, Amos Hochstein, said an end to the fighting was “within our grasp” after meeting in Beirut with Lebanon’s Parliament speaker, a key interlocutor with Hezbollah.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum, Adam Rasgon and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Damage at the site of an Israeli strike in the Zuqaq al-Blat neighborhood of Beirut, Lebanon, on Tuesday.

item.title: Putin Lowers Nuclear Weapons Threshold After U.S. Allows Ukraine to Use Missiles Against Russia
item.description: A decree signed by the Russian leader, though long planned, came days after President Biden authorized the use of U.S.-supplied missiles by Ukraine for strikes inside Russia.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin in Sochi, Russia, this month. His decree on nuclear weapons seemed timed to show that the Kremlin could respond aggressively to Ukrainian strikes with American missiles.

item.title: Brazilian Police Arrest Soldiers in Alleged Plot to Kill President Lula
item.description: Members of an elite army unit planned to kill Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva in 2022 as part of an effort to keep Jair Bolsonaro in power after he lost the presidential election.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva of Brazil defeated Jair Bolsonaro in a close election in 2022.

item.title: Sweden, Finland and Norway Update Crisis Advice as Ukraine-Russia War Grinds On
item.description: Sweden, Finland and Norway have recently updated their advice for citizens preparing to survive war and other crises, wary of Ukraine’s grinding fight against Russia.
item.dc:creator: Christina Anderson, Johanna Lemola, Henrik Pryser Libell and Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Soldiers in a military camp near Heinujarvi, in northern Finland, on Tuesday.

item.title: Delhi Trudges Through Another Air Pollution Nightmare
item.description: The government seems powerless to protect its citizens from this annual crisis, let alone prevent it.
item.dc:creator: Alex Travelli and Hari Kumar
item.media:description: India Gate in New Delhi was enveloped with smog on Tuesday.

item.title: As Pelicot Rape Trial Nears End in France, Wife Speaks of ‘Banality’
item.description: Gisèle Pelicot made her final address to the court, calling the things her husband allegedly did to her ‘unforgivable.’
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:description: Gisèle Pelicot entering the courthouse with her lawyers Stephane Babonneau, center, and Antoine Camus in Avignon, France, on Tuesday.

item.title: Out of Gaza
item.description: We photographed badly wounded Gazans who made it out for treatment. Many can think of little but the dead they left behind. “We wanted to go with them, too,” one child told us.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Dozens of Hong Kong Pro-Democracy Leaders Sentenced in Mass Trial
item.description: The 45 defendants, including Joshua Wong, were at the forefront of the opposition movement crushed by Beijing. Many had already been in jail for years.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May

item.title: Why Michael Learns to Rock Is Big in Asia
item.description: Michael Learns to Rock hoped for success west of their native Denmark. But for 30 years, they’ve had a devoted following on the other side of the world.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:credit: Ezra Acayan for The New York Times

item.title: Magicians Mount Search for Woman Behind Decades-Old Deception
item.description: A British society of magicians expelled a woman for tricking her way into the club in 1991. Now it wants to invite her back, but the woman seems to have pulled a disappearing act.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Neil Munns/PA Images, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The Magic Circle, a society of magicians, expelled a woman who had posed as a man to gain membership. Now the society is trying to track her down.

item.title: U.K. Farmers Protest in London Over Inheritance Tax Change
item.description: Farms worth more than about $1.3 million will face an estate tax from 2026, ending a previous exemption and prompting anger in some rural communities.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Tractors drove past Britain’s Parliament on Tuesday morning, as part of a broader protest by some farmers.

item.title: Is the Russian Army Depleted From Fighting in Ukraine?
item.description: Researchers and journalists have found innovative ways to measure Russia’s ability to keep fighting.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: A cemetery for fallen Russian soldiers in Ulan-Ude, Russia, last year.

item.title: Man Drives Car Into Crowd Outside Primary School in China
item.description: The incident followed an attack by a driver last week that left 35 people dead, and a mass stabbing several days later.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: Social Media, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Netanyahu Offers $5 Million for Each Hostage Freed in Gaza
item.description: As he resists pressure to reach a cease-fire that would release the captives, Israel’s prime minister is now offering a reward for their freedom, while still vowing to punish anyone who hurts a hostage.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has offered a $5 million reward and safe passage out of Gaza to anyone who returns an Israeli captive held in the enclave.

item.title: Biden Fades Out of the Picture in Talks With World Leaders
item.description: As he made his final appearance at global gatherings, including at the Group of 20 summit in Brazil, President Biden lobbied for his foreign policy goals even as leaders shifted attention away from him.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: President Biden and Brazil’s president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, met on Tuesday during a working lunch at the Group of 20 summit in Rio de Janeiro.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: Ukraine hits Russia with U.S. Missiles
item.description: Plus, the Scandinavian band that’s big in Asia.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: John Hamilton/White Sands Missile Range, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The U.S.-made Army Tactical Missile System, known as ATACMS.

item.title: Son of Norway’s Crown Princess Is Arrested on Suspicion of Rape
item.description: Marius Borg Hoiby, the stepson of Crown Prince Haakon of Norway, was arrested on Monday. His lawyer denied the accusation and said his client was cooperating with the authorities.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Hakon Mosvold Larsen/NTB, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Marius Borg Hoiby in 2022. He was 4 when his mother, Crown Princess Mette-Marit of Norway, married Crown Prince Haakon in 2001.

item.title: The Perfect Novel for the Baku Climate Summit: Lydia Kiesling’s Mobility
item.description: The U.N. climate conference, held in a petrostate, is a surreal moment. This darkly funny novel about Baku, oil companies and climate change in the first Trump term helps make sense of it all.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oil fields on the outskirts of Baku, Azerbaijan, in view of the stadium, left, where the U.N. climate summit is taking place.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Ukraine’s new military powers.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers heading toward the Kursk region of Russia.

item.title: Maori Protest Bill That Is Part of Sharp Rightward Shift in New Zealand
item.description: Two small populist parties are responsible for accelerating the shift, which has been felt acutely by the Indigenous Māori.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang

item.title: Mining Company Whose C.E.O. Was Detained Agrees to Pay Mali $160 Million
item.description: Three executives of the Australian company Resolute Mining were arrested this month. Mali, a major African gold producer, has been trying to increase its share of mining profits lately.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean, Saikou Jammeh and Elian Peltier
item.media:description: Bamako, Mali, this month. The country is one of several African countries pushing for a greater share of their valuable minerals in the past few years.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: Ukraine is Poised to Strike inside Russia
item.description: Plus, revelations from a kids’ soccer coach.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers near the Kursk region of Russia in August.

item.title: Gisèle Pelicot’s Sons Tell of a ‘Devastated’ Family at Rape Trial in France
item.description: The men appeared in court, addressing their father, who admits to having drugged their mother over years and inviting dozens of men to rape her while she was unconscious.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:description: Gisèle Pelicot’s sons, David, middle, and Florian, attended the trial of their father in Avignon, France, on Monday.

item.title: Venezuela Frees Over 130 People Imprisoned After Disputed Election
item.description: Experts say the release of some political prisoners may be an attempt by Venezuela’s autocrat to send a signal to President-elect Trump.
item.dc:creator: Isayen Herrera, Julie Turkewitz, Genevieve Glatsky and Adriana Loureiro Fernandez
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jorge Marin, 20, who was detained during the post-election crackdown, was the only prisoner set free on Sunday, the second day of prisoner releases, in Tocorón, Venezuela.

item.title: Looters Strip Aid From About 100 Trucks in Gaza, U.N. Agency Says
item.description: UNRWA, the main U.N. agency aiding Palestinians, said its drivers were forced at gunpoint to unload supplies in what it called one of the worst such incidents of the war.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek and Erika Solomon
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.media:description: Trucks bearing humanitarian aid for the Gaza Strip at the Kerem Shalom crossing in southern Israel last week.

item.title: COP29 Climate Talks in Baku, Azerbaijan, Head Into Final Stretch
item.description: Senior ministers are arriving in an effort to break a deadlock over the summit’s main goal: funding to help lower-income countries hit hard by global warming.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles and Brad Plumer
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
United Nations Convention on Biological Diversity
item.media:description: Mukhtar Babayev, the Azerbaijani official who is presiding over the U.N. climate summit, in Baku on Monday. Some diplomats have expressed frustration with his management of the talks.

item.title: Burglars Break Into Windsor Castle Estate, Home of Prince William, Kate and Family
item.description: The intruders entered a farm building on the castle estate last month and stole an Isuzu pickup and a quad bike, according to the local police.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Windsor Castle in June this year.

item.title: I Tried to Teach My Son Soccer. Here’s What He Taught Me.
item.description: After decades reporting on soccer, three months helping to coach a team of children under age 7 came as a revelation.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mr. Smith and his son at the end of practice.

item.title: Israeli Strikes in Beirut’s Center Shatter a Tenuous Sense of Security
item.description: The strikes, the first in weeks inside Lebanon’s capital, forced residents to come to grips with another escalation of fighting between Israel and Hezbollah.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Hwaida Saad
item.media:description: A Lebanese police officer on Monday at the site of an overnight strike in the Mar Elias neighborhood of Beirut.

item.title: Ukraine Is Poised to Strike Into Russia After Biden Approves Use of Long-Range Missiles
item.description: President Biden has granted permission for Kyiv to carry out long-range strikes, but looming over Ukraine’s newfound latitude is the ascent of President-elect Trump.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Marc Santora and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers in a tank driving toward the Kursk region of Russia in August.

item.title: Coffee, Juice, Shawarma: Tiny Traces of Normal Life in a Ruined Gaza
item.description: Most people in the enclave are struggling just to survive Israel’s assault on Hamas, and experts say famine is imminent. Yet a few pockets of ordinary life have bloomed in defiance of the war.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Bilal Shbair
item.media:description: A street flooded with sewage water in Deir al Balah, Gaza, in July. The city was once known for its restful olive and date palm groves. Now, bombing can shatter the calm in a second.

item.title: As Trump Looms, Biden Makes a Twilight Pitch on Ukraine to Global Leaders
item.description: The president approved Ukraine’s use of long-range missiles inside Russia, but that decision, among others, may soon be reversed.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: President Biden boarding Air Force One in Lima, Peru, on Sunday en route for Rio de Janeiro for the Group of 20 summit.

item.title: Venezuela’s ‘Iron Lady’ Pleads With Trump to Save Her Country’s Democracy
item.description: In a series of rare in-depth interviews, Venezuela’s opposition leader called life in hiding “a difficult test” and asserted that Mr. Trump could gain an early “foreign policy victory” by pushing Nicolás Maduro from office.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: María Corina Machado, Venezuela’s opposition leader, has been in hiding since July.

item.title: Why Oil Companies Are Walking Back From Green Energy
item.description: As leaders gather for a global climate summit, investors are rewarding oil giants like Exxon Mobil that did not embrace wind and solar.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott
item.media:credit: Alisha Jucevic for The New York Times
item.media:description: The difference in profits companies can make from extracting oil and gas and what they can earn from harnessing wind and solar has swung sharply in favor of fossil fuels.

item.title: Alan Jones, Australian Former Radio Host, Arrested on Sexual Abuse Charges
item.description: The retired radio host, who was granted bail after being arrested, was accused of abusing eight victims over nearly 20 years.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: Alan Jones was arrested on Monday morning.

item.title: Emergency Declared as Smog Chokes Parts of India and Pakistan
item.description: The authorities in New Delhi closed schools and urged residents to stay home. Similar measures have been implemented in Punjab, Pakistan’s largest province.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Heavy smog engulfed the skyline of New Delhi, India’s capital, on Sunday.

item.title: Monday Briefing
item.description: A major change in U.S. policy on Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A building in Russian-controlled eastern Ukraine that Russian officials said was hit by U.S.-supplied ATACMS missiles.

item.title: On Migration, Europe Warms to Ideas Once Seen as Fringe
item.description: As in the United States, a decline in the numbers of migrants crossing borders has not stopped anti-migrant sentiments from gaining ground.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross, Steven Erlanger and Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: A police officer near Dunkirk, in northern France, trying to prevent a group of migrants from crossing the English Channel in April.

item.title: What Are ATACMS Missiles? The U.S. Weapons That Ukraine Fired Into Russia
item.description: In a major policy shift, the Biden administration has authorized Ukraine to use the ballistic missiles within Russia.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay and Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: South Korea’s Joint Chiefs of Staff, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: A U.S. Army Tactical Missile System, known as ATACMS, is shown in a photo provided by South Korea’s Joint Chiefs of Staff.

item.title: Celeste Caeiro, Whose Flowers Gave a Name to a Revolt, Dies at 91
item.description: In Portugal in 1974, she spontaneously gave red carnations to soldiers on their way to ending a dictatorship in what became known as the Carnation Revolution.
item.dc:creator: Phil Davison
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Patricia De Melo Moreira/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Celeste Caeiro in April of this year during a 50th-anniversary celebration of the Carnation Revolution, a name she inspired when her flowers were placed in the barrels of soldiers’ rifles during a military coup.

item.title: Monday Briefing: Ukraine Can Hit Russia With U.S. Long-Range Weapons
item.description: Plus, World of Warcraft turned 20.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.media:description: A building in Russian-controlled Ukraine that was damaged in June by ATACMS missiles, according to the Russian Defense Ministry.

item.title: Biden Visits Amazon, Vowing Help to Fight Climate Change
item.description: The president toured the rainforest and promised Brazil funds for environmental initiatives, even as the incoming Trump administration appears poised to roll them back.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova and Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: President Biden after signing a proclamation on Sunday at a museum in Manaus, Brazil, designating Nov. 17 as International Conservation Day. Among those with him is Henrique Pereira, far left, director of the National Institute for Amazon Research.

item.title: What’s New in the Case of the Document Leaks Roiling Israel
item.description: A judge revealed more details about how and why an aide to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu gave sensitive information to the news media.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, center, at the Israeli Parliament’s opening session last month in Jerusalem.

item.title: Biden Allows Ukraine to Strike Russia With Long-Range U.S. Missiles
item.description: With two months left in office, the president for the first time authorized the Ukrainian military to use the system known as ATACMS to help defend its forces in the Kursk region of Russia.
item.dc:creator: Adam Entous, Eric Schmitt and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: A residential building in Luhansk, in Russian-controlled Ukraine, that was damaged in June by U.S.-supplied ATACMS missiles, according to the Russian Defense Ministry. Mr. Biden’s latest authorization allows Ukraine to strike inside Russia.

item.title: Airstrikes Hit Central Beirut for First Time in Weeks
item.description: The attacks came as Israel’s military has been pounding an area just outside the Lebanese capital with some of the heaviest waves of bombardment in months.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner, Euan Ward and Hwaida Saad
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents and rescuers at the site of an Israeli airstrike on Sunday in central Beirut, Lebanon.

item.title: Israeli Strikes in Central and Northern Gaza Kill More Than 30 People
item.description: As Israel’s military wages a renewed offensive in the northern part of the enclave, Al Bureij and Nuseirat in central Gaza came under attack.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek
item.media:description: Outside a hospital in central Gaza on Sunday, a woman mourned victims of an Israeli airstrike.

item.title: Haiti Has Big Problems and Few Solutions
item.description: A search for a solution to the crisis in Haiti is growing more urgent as gangs gain territory and thousands more flee their homes.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: A small market in the downtown of Port-au-Prince, the Haitian capital. Many streets are empty as people fear gang violence.

item.title: Barnard’s Star Finally Has a Planet, and Possibly More
item.description: For a century, exoplanet hunters have “discovered” planets around a nearby star, only to retract the claims. But the latest find is for real.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye

item.title: Why Trump’s Space for Deal-Making in the Middle East Has Shrunk
item.description: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s agenda in the region is not yet clear, but the geopolitical landscape has changed significantly since he was last in office.
item.dc:creator: Mark Mazzetti
item.media:description: Smoke from an Israeli airstrike over south Beirut this week. The political landscape of the Middle East has shifted considerably since the end of last Trump administration.

item.title: Russia Bombards Power Grid in One of War’s Largest Attacks, Ukraine Says
item.description: The attack lasted hours and involved around 120 missiles and 90 drones, officials in the country said. At least nine people were killed.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Surveying a damaged roof on a residential building in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Sunday after a Russian strike.

item.title: At a Ukraine Maternity Clinic, Deaths From an Airstrike Shatter a Community
item.description: It was one horrific day of the war in Ukraine when a missile fell on the Adonis clinic in Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Kim Barker and Brendan Hoffman
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times

item.title: ‘No Use for Hatred’: A Village Seeks to Move On From a U.S. Massacre
item.description: The hamlet of My Lai is infamous for American war crimes, but now it holds lessons in resilience and how to let go of anger.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Linh Pham for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I survived because the Americans shooting everyone ran out of bullets,” said Nguyen Hong Mang, who was 14 when American soldiers came to his village.

item.title: Man Hiding Tarantulas, Centipedes and Ants Is Stopped From Boarding Flight
item.description: Officials in Lima, Peru, said the endangered spiders had been taken from the Amazon basin. The man was flying to South Korea.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.media:description: One of the tarantulas that were seized at the international airport that serves Peru’s capital, Lima.

item.title: Vladimir Shklyarov, Star Russian Ballet Dancer, Dies at 39
item.description: The Mariinsky Theater in St. Petersburg, which announced the death, did not say how or where he died.
item.dc:creator: Milana Mazaeva and Alan Yuhas
item.media:credit: Hiroyuki Ito for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vladimir Shklyarov performing in “Etudes” at the City Center in New York in 2008.

item.title: Biden and Xi Meet, Delivering Messages Seemingly Intended for Trump
item.description: Donald J. Trump has promised a more aggressive approach, after the Biden administration worked to avoid open conflict with Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:description: President Biden and the Chinese leader, Xi Jinping, meeting on Saturday in Lima, Peru.

item.title: China Stabbing Kills at Least 8 People
item.description: The stabbing, in the eastern city of Wuxi, took place days after a man drove a vehicle into a crowd in southern China, killing dozens.
item.dc:creator: Claire Fu and Alan Yuhas
item.media:description: The city of Wuxi, China, where the stabbing attack happened on Saturday night.

item.title: South Africa Police Try Siege Tactics on Illegal Mining, Igniting Debate
item.description: The police have cut off food and water to miners for weeks in a bid to force them out of an abandoned mine. Human rights advocates and community leaders call the tactics inhumane.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A disused mine where hundreds of men accused of illegal mining are hiding in Stilfontein, South Africa, on Friday.
